block-definition.comment: Reports a new list whose items are the same as in the input list, except that if two or more equal items appear in the input list, only the last one is kept in the result.

Reports a sorted version of the list in its first input slot, using the comparison function in the second input slot. For a list of numbers, using < as the comparison function will sort from low to high; using > will sort from high to low.

The second input is an "association list," a list of two-item lists. Each of those smaller lists has a "key" as its first item and a "value" as its second. ASSOC reports the first key-value pair in the association list whose key matches the first input.

This block carries out the given script for each item of the given list, like the primitive FOR EACH. What's different is that it provides the # variable, which will contain the item number in the list of each item in turn, 1 while processing item 1, and so on.
Takes a (possibly deep) list as input, and reports a human-readable text form of the list (namely, Lisp notation). Will not work on circular lists.

SENTENCE is the main constructor for sentences, represented as lists of words. It takes zero or more inputs, each of which can be either a list or a text string. If a list, the input is assumed to be a list of words. If a text string, it is converted to a list of words using SENTENCE→LIST. Then all the lists of words are appended to form a new list of words. If the inputs are lists of lists rather than lists of words, SENTENCE, like APPEND, does only one level of flattening, reporting a list of all the items of all the input lists.

ZIP takes any number of lists as inputs. The lists should all be the same length. ZIP reports a list of lists in which the first item is a list of all the first items, the second item is a list of all the second items, etc. Viewing the inputs as the rows of a matrix, ZIP reports its transpose.
The identity function reports its input.

Takes as input a function of N inputs and N lists. The function is called with item 1 of all the lists as its inputs, with item 2 of all the lists as its inputs, and so on. (The lists should all be the same length.)
Takes a sentence in text string form and reports the sentence as a list of its words.
block-definition.translations: de:Satz $arrowRight Liste _ ca:frase $arrowRight llista _ es:frase $arrowRight lista _ fr:phrase $arrowRight liste _ pt:uma lista com as palavras da frase _

custom-block.l: Synchronization Requested Sending SYN Packet
Synchronization Not Requested Goodbye
SYN-ACK Compiled Sending SYN-ACK Packet
Wrong SYN-ACK Compiled Goodbye
ACK Compiled Sending ACK Packet
Wrong ACK Compiled Goodbye
ACK Compiled Sending ACK Packet
Wrong ACK Compiled Goodbye

scripts.comment: devi aggiungere: - l'eliminazione dal buffer dei segmenti di cui si è inviato l'ack (più o meno fatto, cioè fatto nella versione per cui non ci sono mai errori nella comunicazione - versione sufficiente) - un timer al client quando finisce di inviare il messaggio che se paasano più di x round senza ricevere ack dà per persi tutti i segmenti di cui non ha ricevuto l'ack e li rimanda (dovrebbe essere fatto ed è stato implementato per ogni segmento) - il modo di riordinare il buffer del receiver e controllare ad ogni segmento che arriva se il buffer è in ordine così può decidere se inviare o meno ack cumulativo

block.l: What is the message that you want to send?

block.comment: meaning if the timer for receiving the ACK for the segment dropped to zero

list.l: Missing ACK for the segment containing up to the
bits of the message corrinsponding to the message part

block.comment: This list is used to simulate a segment saved in the buffer (in this case in the sender buffer but the same structure will be used also in the receiver buffer). Since it would not be possible to save the entire segment for each simulated segment saved it will be written the segment number and the number of bits that are sent thanks to that segment. Once that the cumulative ACKs from the receiver will arrive all the segment with a number of bits lower or equal to the one resulting form (receiver ack number - sender sequence number) will be removed from the sender buffer. As for the receiver the segment will be inserted in the buffer if the segment does not arrive in order (meaning sender sequence number + number of bits sent != receiver ack number)
meaning that the sender received an ACK for all the segment that had to send and so the message has been completely received in a correct way

block.l: Message correctley sent and received. Preparing for closing the connection

block.comment: devi controllare poi se questo controllo va realmente bene, nel senso che devi fare controllo quando il segmento che arriva non è realmente il più grande (perché i segmenti possono non arrivare in ordine) perché in quel caso non devono rimanere quelli maggiori di segment number ma quelli maggiori del numero più grande tra quelli in ordine

block.l: Waiting for more data. Buffering the segment
Segment not in order. Waiting for previous segments to send ACK
Wrong Checksum, data corrupted. Segment discarded

block.comment: meaning if the buffer is in order and has all the segment that it needs to send the ack

custom-block.l: Declare Window Size to start Data sending

block.l: On which component do you want to know more?
Not a component of the TCP header
The Client Sequence Number generated is
Write the value of the SYN flag
The Server Sequence Number generated is
Write the value of the SYN flag
Write the value of the ACK flag
Write the value of the ACK flag
What is the size of the window (buffer)?
Window size not legal (0 <= window size <= 65535)
Write the value of the ACK flag

custom-block.l: The Source Port identifies the port number on the sender host associated with the TCP connection. The port is chosen among the dynamic ports (ranging from 49152 to 65535) by the os' networking stack

The Destination Port identifies the port number on the receiving host associated with the TCP connection. The value of this field depends on the specific application. Some common values are: - Port 80 for HTTP traffic - Port 443 for HTTPS traffic - Port 25 for SMTP traffic

The Sequence Number indicates the offset (expressed in bytes) of the start of the TCP segment within the complete flow, from the Initial Sequence Number (ISN), decided upon opening the connection (used to reassemble the data)

The Acknowledgement Number has meaning only if the ACK flag is set to 1, and confirms receipt of a portion of the data stream in the opposite direction, indicating the value of the next Sequence number that the TCP segment sender host expects to receive.

The Header Length indicates the length (in 32-bit dwords) of the TCP segment header; this length can vary from 5 dwords (20 bytes) to 15 dwords (60 bytes) depending on the presence and length of the Options optional field.
The Reserved Bits are bits not used and set up for future protocol developments; they should be set to zero.
The URG Flag if set to 1 indicates that there is urgent data in the stream at the position (offset) indicated by the Urgent pointer field. Urgent Pointer points to the end of the urgent data
The ACK Flag if set to 1 indicates that the Acknowledgment number field is valid
The PSH Flag if set to 1 indicates that incoming data should not be buffered but passed immediately to higher levels of the application
The RST Flag if set to 1 indicates that the connection is invalid; used in case of a serious error; sometimes used in conjunction with the ACK flag to close a connection.

The SYN Flag if set to 1 indicates that the host sending the segment wants to open a TCP connection with the receiving host and specifies in the Sequence number field the value of the Initial Sequence Number (ISN); it is intended to synchronize the sequence numbers of the two hosts. The host that sent the SYN must wait for a SYN/ACK packet from the remote host.

The FIN Flag if set to 1 indicates that the sender host of the segment wants to close the TCP connection opened with the receiver host. The sending host waits for confirmation from the receiving host (with a FIN-ACK). At this point the connection is considered half closed: the host that sent FIN can no longer send data, while the other host has the communication channel still available. When the other host also sends the packet with FIN set, the connection, after the corresponding FIN-ACK, is considered completely closed.

The Window Size (or Advertisement Window) indicates the size of the sender host's receiving window, that is, the number of bytes the sender is able to accept from that specified by the acknowledgment number.

The Checksum field is used for checking the validity of the segment. It is obtained by doing the 1's complement of the 16-bit one's complement sum of the entire TCP header (with the checksum field set to zero), the entire payload, with the addition of a pseudo header consisting of: source IP address (32bit),destination IP address (32bit), a byte of zeros, a byte indicating the protocol, and two bytes indicating the length of the TCP packet (header + data).
The Urgent Pointer is a pointer to urgent data, has meaning only if the URG flag is set to 1 and indicates the offset in bytes from the Sequence number of the byte of urgent data within the stream.
The Option Field is a field for options (optional) for advanced protocol uses.
The Data represents the payload to be transmitted i.e., the PDU coming from the upper layer.
Simulation ended Execute again to retry it
